text:
Just registered [Ueauty](<https://gitlab.com/ExpandingMan/Ueauty.jl>) for simple, universally recognized unicode aliases with zero package dependencies.  My evil plan is to make the remaining "blindingly obvious" unicode aliases that are not in `Base` so common that nobody will be able to argue against putting them in `Base`
```using Ueauty; @ueauty

# Integer abstract type
f(n::‚Ñ§) = n + 1

# Real abstract type, summation with \sum (distinct from \Sigma)
g(v::Vector{<:‚Ñù}) = ‚àë(v)

# Complex abstract type, product with \prod (distinct from \Pi)
h(v::Vector{<:‚ÑÇ}) = ‚àè(v)

# \infty for floating point Inf
typemax(Float64) == ‚àû 

# \scri for the imaginary unit
‚ÑØ^(ùíæ*œÄ) ‚âà -1.0

# \Rightarrow for pairs
Dict(:a‚áí1, :b‚áí2)

# \triangleright for |> pipe operator
rand(5) ‚ñ∑ ‚àë ‚ñ∑ sinh```

so common that nobody will be able to argue against putting them in
Base

using Ueauty; @ueauty

# Integer abstract type
f(n::‚Ñ§) = n + 1

# Real abstract type, summation with \sum (distinct from \Sigma)
g(v::Vector{<:‚Ñù}) = ‚àë(v)

# Complex abstract type, product with \prod (distinct from \Pi)
h(v::Vector{<:‚ÑÇ}) = ‚àè(v)

# \infty for floating point Inf
typemax(Float64) == ‚àû 

# \scri for the imaginary unit
‚ÑØ^(ùíæ*œÄ) ‚âà -1.0

# \Rightarrow for pairs
Dict(:a‚áí1, :b‚áí2)

# \triangleright for |> pipe operator
rand(5) ‚ñ∑ ‚àë ‚ñ∑ sinh

text:
Might be worth adding a warning about this:
```julia> 2+2 ‚ñ∑ sqrt
3.414213562373095

julia> Base.operator_precedence(:(‚ñ∑))
12

julia> Base.operator_precedence(:(|>))
9```
`‚áí` also has slightly higher precedence, but I can‚Äôt seem to make it go wrong.

text:
This package is eye candy, but I'm a little concerned about the impact a package would have to accessibility of Julia.
‚Ä¢ A person has to fix a Julia script in using Nano on some server and can't type unicode characters. What happens if Unicode is now rampant across the Julia ecosystem?
‚Ä¢ People have to have a math degree - or at least math university education to get what `foo(::‚Ñ§)` means. This kind of advanced mathematical notation is not clear unless you've studied it
‚Ä¢ I wouldn't be comfortable forcing people to use a font that is able to display all sorts of Unicode characters in order to be able to use Julia

elements.text: This package is eye candy, but I'm a little concerned about the impact a package would have to accessibility of Julia.
A person has to fix a Julia script in using Nano on some server and can't type unicode characters. What happens if Unicode is now rampant across the Julia ecosystem?
People have to have a math degree - or at least math university education to get what
foo(::‚Ñ§)
means. This kind of advanced mathematical notation is not clear unless you've studied it
I wouldn't be comfortable forcing people to use a font that is able to display all sorts of Unicode characters in order to be able to use Julia

text:
Point by point:
- It's already pretty common, and there are already a ton of aliases in `Base`.  All editor that are at all likely to be used for coding have the capability to do latex to unicode, though you are right about cases where people don't have the plugin.
- I completely reject that notion.  For one thing, high school students and first year undergards are asked to deal with that notation all the time, but that's besides the point.  If you see it the first time, it's unexpected, but then you quickly learn what it means and move on, that's just life.  After all they are just some aliases, you don't need to have a real grasp on the axioms of the real numbers to use a Julia `Real`.
- I would agree with you here if I felt this was really the case, but fortunately the majority of monospace fonts are good enough to be legible.  There's nothing here that's likely to "totally break" on a "normal" setup.  Same goes for the stuff that's already in `Base` of course.  Yes, JuliaMono is better, but by no means do you get gibberish if you don't use this.  I agree this is a valid concern, and I *would* consider it if adding any new aliases.

text:
<@U7HAYKY9X> As a devil's advocate I'll retort with
‚Ä¢ I'm pretty sure that this is not an issue-- I'm pretty sure unicode encoding happens at the client and is sent across the wire. I mean, a default installation of nano doesn't have that any facilities for backslash-tab-completion, but it does have copy-paste.
‚Ä¢ Definitely doesn't take a math degree to parse the sentence "‚Ñ§ is the integers".
‚Ä¢ This is kind of like the 80-column terminal support argument which Linus Torvalds recently admonished people for, and I think the resolution is the same-- it's 2021 and this maybe isn't a demographic we should be designing our code for.

elements.text: As a devil's advocate I'll retort with

I'm pretty sure that this is not an issue-- I'm pretty sure unicode encoding happens at the client and is sent across the wire. I mean, a default installation of nano doesn't have that any facilities for backslash-tab-completion, but it does have copy-paste.
Definitely doesn't take a math degree to parse the sentence "‚Ñ§ is the integers".

This is kind of like the 80-column terminal support argument which Linus Torvalds recently admonished people for, and I think the resolution is the same-- it's 2021 and this maybe isn't a demographic we should be designing our code for.

text:
‚Ä¢ Right, but you need a client that can type unicode. E.g. you need an editor with shortcuts to type it, else you need to resort to copy-pasting symbols. Not exactly user friendly.
‚Ä¢ It doesn't? I never learned what ‚Ñ§ means, even in university. Pretty sure only physics/chemists/mathematicians/engineers know that. IIRC, we didn't even learn ‚àë in high school (could be wrong) And it's completely unnecessary when you can just type "Integer" or "sum", which requires no special knowledge.
‚Ä¢ Maybe that one is right. I'd be interested in hearing from a bunch of people on the last point. My computer don't have problems displaying most unicode characters, perhaps that worry is outdated

Maybe that one is right. I'd be interested in hearing from a bunch of people on the last point. My computer don't have problems displaying most unicode characters, perhaps that worry is outdated

text:
- Right, you need an editor that can type it.  I think we're just going to disagree about that being an acceptable cost.
- Yet, somehow, right now, you know what it means.  It probably didn't take you very long to learn either, somebody just said "`\bbZ` is integers!" and you learned it.  If you spoke German, you might already guess from the context what it means.
- Yeah, if we lived in a world where this stuff or the stuff in base were broken for most fonts, while I might be extremely annoyed that I can't use nice aliases because of tooling, I just wouldn't use it.  If most people doing non-crazy things just couldn't read it, I'd find it unacceptable.  There probably wouldn't even be any aliases in `Base` and nobody woudl use them anywya, were that the case.

text: More broadly, I like to emphasize that while, yes unicode aliases can look pretty, this is *NOT* purely aesthetic, it serves an important functional purpose.  Reading code is a lot more important that writing it, I deal every day with code that is perfectly easy to read in Julia because it looks almost like it does in latex formulation.  Others at my company have similar things in python with extremely verbose names and it's totally unreadable.  Being able to glance at code and know exactly what it's going to do is a *HUGE* benefit, it's not just happy fun times with pretty characters (though it's that also)

text:
‚Ä¢ My Conemu on windows still struggle a bit with unicode
‚Ä¢ A google search for ‚Ñ§ had quite interesting results for me
‚Ä¢ AFAIK there is no way to reverse engineer how to type a unicode symbol even if you have it, and it has be a hassle for me at some point in the past
All that being said I like these unicode alias, and the problem I had are of tooling and documentation more than something against the principle itself.

AFAIK there is no way to reverse engineer how to type a unicode symbol even if you have it, and it has be a hassle for me at some point in the past
All that being said I like these unicode alias, and the problem I had are of tooling and documentation more than something against the principle itself.

text:
FWIW, I don't ever recall learning "Z is integers". "R is reals" I do recall. But I also don't have a need to use the "Real" type. I don't think most even think about them unless you're doing advanced mathematics, and they don't make much sense to use outside that domain.

I think sum and product notation is a lot more common, as well as infinity and imaginary i.

elements.text:

I think sum and product notation is a lot more common, as well as infinity and imaginary i.

text:
Perhaps a lot of folks have never learned about what the symbol `‚Ñ§` represented-- that's completely fair. I think it stands that this syntax is not so hard to _understand_ that it would serve as a substantial barrier to entry into the Julia language, e.g. if someone were perusing some code that made heavy-use of Ueauty.

On the contrary, I can imagine a person unfamiliar with `‚Ñ§` might stop, figure it out, and all of a sudden have a concise way to express something useful.

text: I use `Real` a fair amount... basically anytime can take something that's either a float or an integer, perhaps if you want to allow something to be passed as an integer that is internally a float, so I don't think it's uncommon

text: Interesting, `‚Ñï, ‚Ñ§, ‚Ñö, ‚Ñù` was the sort of trivia our (early high school?) teachers adored, but clearly this was not universal. Although I have never seen `‚Ñï` since‚Ä¶ I think it was counting numbers 1,2,3, but wikipedia now tells me that (of course) there are both both 1-based and 0-based users.
